importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The day before the IMO vote, President Trump made a public threat on Truth Social against the proposed carbon tax on shipping, directly influencing the decision to delay adoption.
The final decision to postpone the Net Zero Framework adoption was announced on this date, marking a significant setback in global shipping emissions regulation.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The Net Zero Framework was originally set to be formally adopted in late 2025, but the delay pushes its implementation to late 2026, significantly extending the timeline for global shipping emissions reductions.

keyTakeAways: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) postponed the formal adoption of the Net Zero Framework (NZF) by at least 12 months due to pressure from U.S. President Donald Trump.
Trump threatened sanctions, visa restrictions, and port levies on countries that supported the carbon tax on shipping, influencing the vote in London.
The NZF would have been the first global carbon-pricing system, imposing a $380 per metric tonne penalty on excess CO2 emissions from ships and rewarding emission reductions.
The framework aims to reduce shipping emissions by 20% by 2030 and eliminate them by 2050, aligning with global climate goals.
Key supporters included China, the EU, Brazil, Britain, and several other IMO members, while Russia and Saudi Arabia opposed it.
The International Chamber of Shipping expressed disappointment, noting the need for clarity to make investments in decarbonization.
Vanuatu’s climate minister called the delay 'unacceptable' given the urgency of climate change, emphasizing the role of international law.
The decision undermines global cooperation on climate action and may weaken efforts to combat climate change in the shipping sector.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) delayed the formal adoption of its Net Zero Framework (NZF), a global carbon-pricing system designed to reduce shipping emissions, by at least 12 months after U.S. President Donald Trump threatened sanctions on countries supporting the plan. Trump's public statement on Truth Social, calling the measure a 'Global Green New Scam Tax,' led to a shift in the vote, with 57 members backing a postponement to late 2026. Key supporters like China, the EU, and Brazil had previously backed the framework, while Russia and Saudi Arabia opposed it. The NZF would have imposed a $380 penalty per metric tonne of excess CO2 emissions, aiming for a 20% reduction in shipping emissions by 2030 and net zero by 2050. The delay has been criticized by climate officials and shipping industry leaders as a setback to global climate efforts, undermining progress in decarbonizing maritime transport and raising concerns about the role of political interference in environmental policy.
title: Trump torpedoes international deal to reduce shipping emissions
